modules.description: Provides operations to retrieve and manipulate the current working directory as a path string. Works with string-based file paths and leverages the process's current directory context. Used to construct absolute paths for file operations or to reset the working directory after temporary changes.

Provides functions to determine process creation strategy based on environment variables, using either fork or vfork. Works with a custom type representing the process creation method. Used to configure process spawning behavior in Unix-based systems.

Creates an environment structure from a list of key-value string pairs, parsing each into a structured format. Operates on string-based key-value representations and returns a typed environment container. Used to initialize configuration contexts from command-line arguments or external configuration files.

Creates and manipulates process group identifiers, allowing the assignment of a new process group based on a process ID. Operates on integer-based process group IDs, ensuring valid values through strict positivity checks. Used to establish isolated process groups for task management in system-level operations.

Provides a function to start a command in the background with support for specifying a working directory, enhanced error handling for missing files or directories, and performance optimizations using vfork on Unix. Works with process execution and file system paths. Used to launch long-running tasks or external programs with precise control over environment and error conditions.

manages directory paths, process creation strategies, environment configurations, and process group identifiers. It handles string-based paths, custom process creation types, key-value environment data, and integer process group IDs. Users can construct absolute paths, configure process spawning methods, build typed environments from strings, and assign process groups for isolation. Examples include resetting the working directory, selecting fork or vfork based on environment settings, parsing command-line arguments into environments, and grouping processes for control.
